result.execSummary:
The defendant James H. Weber was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. James H. Weber is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • James H. Weber was found guilty of Operate with Restricted Controlled Substance (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(am).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
*Pay fine plus costs/surcharges 
*If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy.
*Engage and comply with any other counseling reasonably related to the offense as recommended by the agent.

timeConds.notes:
*Eligible for huber priviliges 
*Eligible for the GPS electronic home monitor after serving 100 days of the jail sentence
*Jail sentence to start in 3 weeks

records.addlTxt: Associated with Charge #2

Defendant James H. Weber in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. Michael Daniel Zell appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
9:04 a.m ADA Zell calls the case and states the appearances.
Cases being heard today 15CF469, 17CF200, & 17CF373.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
ADA Zell states plea agreement.
Atty Kryshak concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
15CF469:
Count 1: Dismissed
Count 2: NO CONTEST

17CF200:
Count 1: DRI

17CF373:
Count 1: DRI

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty of 15CF469 Count 2.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date. 15CF469 Count 1 is dismissed. 17CF200 is DRI. 17CF373 is DRI.

ADA Zell makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Kryshak makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 

BY THE COURT:
15CF469 Count 2: **PROBATION**
Sentence Withheld
36 months Probation
Conditions of Probabtion:
Pay $600.00 fine + costs and surcharges.
Pay $26.45 Blood Draw Fee
180 days conditional jail, eligible for huber. Eligible for electronic monitor after serving 100 days. 
Jail sentence to start in 3 weeks
28 months Drivers License Revocation
28 months IID
Engage and comply in any other counseling reasonably related to the offense as recommended by the Agent.
Complete an Alcohol/Drug Assessment or Department of Transportation Driver Safety Plan and comply with any recommendations.
Plea/sentencing hearing on August 23, 2017 at 08:30 am.

2:32 p.m. Defendant James H. Weber in court with attorney Erik John Mcfarland. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Motion to Suppress as to Probable Cause and Motion as to Search Warrant.
ADA Knaapen calls witness, Officer Christy Ahrens, who is sworn in and testifies during direct exam. Exhibit P#1 is marked and referred to during direct exam. ADA Knaapen moves for the Court to recieve Exhibit P#1. No objections. BTC: Exhibit P#1 is received.
2:59 p.m. Cross exam by Atty McFarland. Exhibit D#2 is marked and referred to during direct exam.
3:24 p.m. ADA Knaapen re-direct exam.
3:36 p.m. Atty McFarland recross.
3:38 p.m. ADA Knaapen final arguments objecting to Motions.
3:45 p.m. Atty McFarland final arguments in support of Motions.
3:52 p.m. ADA Knaapen further final statements.


BTC:  There was no intential falsehood or reckless disregard and finds there were sufficient reasons to issue the search warrant.  Court denies the Motions.
Parties schedule trial and final pretrial.

4:14 p.m. Court in recess.  Jury trial scheduled for October 26, 2016 at 08:30 am.  Final pre-trial scheduled for October 11, 2016 at 11:00 am.
